subject: Ethics
title: Deterrence Theory Problems
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Deterrence Theory Problems.

hook.text: Nuclear deterrence works perfectlyâ€”until it doesn't. And it only needs to fail once.

buildup.text: Deterrence theory says possessing weapons you never plan to use prevents others from attacking.

discovery.text: For deterrence to work, you must convincingly threaten to kill millions of civilians. That's the plan.

twist.text: If deterrence fails and you launch, you're committing genocide. If you don't launch, deterrence was a bluff.

climax.text: The strategy requires permanently holding a gun to civilization's head and hoping nobody flinches.

punchline.text: A gun you never fire still terrorizes everyone in the room.

quiz.question: What is the central paradox of nuclear deterrence theory?
options: Nuclear weapons are too expensive to maintain but too dangerous to dismantle
Deterrence requires threatening genocide, but actually launching would be genocide
Only democracies can practice deterrence because autocracies are unpredictable
